Le jeu 14/08/2003 � 00:34, Alex Jacobson a �crit :

> So when a client sends a GET, it expects the information identified by the
> resource. If "whatever information" means ALL information without data
> loss, the client can reasonably interpret the response to a GET to *BE* the
> server's representation. (Obviously when the client sends an Accept
> header, it accepting non-fidelity to the server's actual representation,
> but that is really beside the point here. GET without an Accept header
> implies fidelity).
> """"""

So suppose that a messaging system can accept in a POST mime/rfc822,
xmtp,rss-rdf fragments, latex letter, etc. and stores messages in an
rbds. What is the "without data loss" server representation... the SQL
??
and if if parse all those formats to deal with message objects, having
methods and so on... what is the "without data loss" server
representation? the serialized object ?


> In what sense does POSTing an RNA notification imply a request that it be 
> accepted as a new subordinate of the inbox?
> What does it mean for a notification to be a new subordinate of an inbox?
> 

What does it mean for /you/ for a resource to be subordinate to an other
? it is not related to the uri, since they are opaque. It is not a
'index' question, since a file is subordinate to a directory (see rfc)
and when you get a directory (at least in Apache) you get an index and
not the content. Do you mean that Apache violate http ?
So what is subordination ? For me, it is just a kind of "relational
integrity" in rdbs (foreign keys, on.. cascade, trigers...) 
an message(mid,from,date,body) table is subordinate to a
box(title,id,desc) by sub(box.id,message.mid). You can select an index
(i.e. just all the ids of messages in the box) or an archive (all
messages) and to delete a box mean to delete all messages it contains.
But boxes and messages have there own namespaces (uri in the rest world)
This is how I understand subordination. (I don't mean that ressources
must be stored in an rdbs, it is just an analogy).
